text: Hi everyone and welcome to the session
that's about creating an interactive
model for uh Sweden's largest stadium.
So to give a brief introduction, my name
is Jonathan Redell. I'm an architect
turned into a visualizer and I've been
the principal Unreal Engine artist who's
uh worked primarily with the stadium
projects among other large scale
interactive projects developed at my
company A3.
So to just give a brief agenda over what
this presentation is about, we can just
cite the introductory text and see that
it's about utilizing key technologies
such as megalytes, lumen and nanites. We
at AP for experience studios, we've kind
of created a large scale interactive
models for three stadiums in the city of
Goththingberg, Sweden.
So these interactive stadiums will be
used for an ecosystem of ROIs that is
return on investments including event
planning, marketing, recruitment,
interactive site guides, security
planning and training and arena
development as well. So this
presentation will go through the kind of
the story of how we created these and
what they're used for and most
importantly actually will be used for.
So yeah, we'll go through the story of
this project. So we'll go through the
first brief and that kind of sets the
foundation of how we began with creating
this arena model in a real. We then have
the big remake that we did after we
finished our first brief.
We'll also go through the challenges of
creating these arenas models and all of
its uses. And then we'll discuss the
return on investments and value this
model will actually then provide and
looking at it through kind of the
technical lens of Unreal Engine. And
then to finish we just have some
takeaways as well uh that we've gotten
from this entire project.
But then who are the stakeholders and
who's involved in this whole project. So
it all starts with client G events. They
manage all of the stadiums in
Goththingberg. They handle around nine
stadiums in total but we'll just focus
on the three biggest ones. And then
alongside Gut events we have an overall
art director who's worked with the
client before. Uh that's the company
Vissolent.
We then have Abako architects. They have
the framework agreements with all of the
stadiums in Goththingberg and they take
care of all of the architectural
planning for these event spaces. And
then we have us at Afrey Hur, the Unreal
consultants who created the actual
interactive solutions for these
stadiums. And so all of these parties,
they've worked very closely with each
other to try to get as good a result as
possible. And that I mean we've been
able to inform and help each other
during this entire process. So it hasn't
been really a handover situation and the
same very many other projects work
and so the projects where is it the
project and the stadiums they're
residing in Goththingberg which is
Sweden's second largest city. So it lies
on the west coast and has about 600,000
inhabitants.
So the city itself, it's very known for
its industrial business ventures and
also very much in its events and
entertainment industry and it also has a
very close connection to seafood and
fish. And so in the city core there's
what's called the venue block and it's
kind of a central part where all of
these three stadiums we're going to talk
about lie in very close proximity to
each other.
So they're quite just smack dab in the
middle of the city and it's walking
distance between these three large
stadiums. And so they're new olivy
and Scandinavian.
And to give a bit of a info about the
clients. So it's the client company good
events who requested this model to be
made and good event. They're part
actually of Goththingberg municipality
and Gothberg city. So they manage all
large scale events in Goththingberg. And
then the actual brief has been done to
create an interactive model for the
indoor arena Scandinavian as seen on the
image. So here they wanted to see kind
of how we could take a simple BIM model
that's a building information model and
translate it into an interactive
experience in Unreal Engine. And so the
actual delivery itself was very much
more of an exploratory handover and it
didn't really have a sharp deadline or
requirement specification. There was
this fundamental idea of what the model
would be used for, but we just simply
had to see what the design process
unlocked. And that's something our
clients very much encouraged us to do
and it's quite unique in this type of
setting.
So if we just take a look at these
venues from small to big, so this is
where we actually begin our journey.
It's in Scandinavian. It's an indoor
arena with a capacity of 14,000 sitting
people. It was built in 1971, so it can
actually be considered quite aged in
modern standards.
But then this arena as well will be
replaced with a new venue. But then it's
also gone through very many developments
over the years and because of these
development there exists an up-to-ate 3D
model of the arena and that's
essentially the reason why we began with
Scandinavia and it also helps that it's
kind of the smallest arena of the three
we made.
And then we have the middle child. It's
the stadium old Ulvie. It has a capacity
of around 18,000 people and it's
actually built later in 2009. So, it's
the newest building, but I mean the
space has been used for football for
over a hundred years. So, the actual use
of the place can be considered quite
old. And then this arena is only used
for football or soccer. And it's
Gothberg's home teams usually battle it
out in this space. And last but not
least is Nia Olivy or New Oliv Sweden's
largest stadium. So, it has a capacity
of 75,000 people. around 40,000 of those
are seats and it was built in 1958 as
well. So it's quite an old stadium but
it's also undergone some expansions and
modernizations throughout the years. And
then I mean since it's the largest
stadium in Sweden, the biggest artists
in the world has often used this as a
venue. So I mean if a world artist has
played in Sweden, they have with all
probability played here.
But the first brief was about
Scandinavian, the indoor arena. And we
didn't really know what to expect
because quite early on we realized that
in an arena such as this, you only think
about the public spaces. And now we
really had to dig deep into the arena
and the function of it. We just realized
that an arena is so much more than just
the spaces that are for the public.
And because we're in Sweden, we should
just learn a little Swedish phrase
called
Maka, which means we just slid in on a
shrimp sandwich because people as people
with kind of an offline rendering
background as we had, it was quite a big
step to go from rendering just some
exterior or interior images of the
stadiums to now just making a fully
interactive model of an entire arena. So
we just managed to slide in on a shrimp
sandwich because this was the first big
project the Arcus team got to do with
Unreal. So it was very nice to be
offered this opportunity. So just like
this expression indicates, it was handed
to us on a silver platter.
And then compared with traditional
Arcis, we just noticed right away a big
difference in the pre-planning. So it's
a much larger process of collecting all
of the data for this project and mapping
it out because then I mean in comparison
with a traditional Arcist project for an
image or an animation you as the artist
do you really control the narrative of
what the user will experience but then
in an interactive Unreal model you don't
really have that luxury. You don't know
how the user will navigate around the
model and what kind of level of detail
they will look at. So in that way we're
really forced to collect so much more
information about the space.
So we took over 500 pictures of
everything in the space from the large
grand arena room to the small nooks and
crannies of the basement and space that
you never visit as a visitor in the
arena. So we did this over two periods
seeing as though I mean even though you
take loads of pictures you often miss
something and that becomes quite
important after a while and you just
must supplement your album with
additional pictures and angles.
And we didn't only just take reference
images to create this. But then in order
to actually create the recognizable
space, we had to do a lot of texture
collection to get the right feel kind of
within the model because you can't
really fake things behind the camera or
use Photoshop to fix things like we did
before. You just have to be very
thorough. And in Unreal, what you see is
actually what you get.
And that's also kind of related to how
we treated the model data and how we
looked at the workflow of working
through this project with several
people. So we treated the BIM model as
kind of the data model and that was the
considered the most correct model that
existed. So we weren't allowed to do any
changes to the BIM model except for
actually detailing the already existing
geometry. So we didn't move walls or
remove or add major things in the arena.
we just I mean we had to inform the
architects if we did that. So that our
model just didn't digress from the kind
of correct data model. So this was all
just a continuous loop workflow between
us and architects and how we plan our
workflow. And it's been kind of very
important to keep both sets of models
accurate.
And so after we've done all of this
pre-process work, it was about kind of
getting it into Unreal Engine. So the
architects they work with Revit and we
primarily work with 3ds Max and then we
needed to bring that into Unreal. So
since we wanted to keep as many
workflows that we are familiar with as
possible, we did all of the further
modeling and detailing in 3ds Max and
then we brought it in with the Datasmith
importer. I mean with the amount of data
and the number of iterations that had to
be made, we just felt like Unreal's
Datasmith what was worked best in taking
the arena and just updating it over
time.
And so the model itself, it was worked
on very much in parallel between Unreal
and Max. And we in a way just ignore the
kind of proper visual data prepping that
you can do in a real. So instead, our
special solution, if you will, consisted
of texturing the 3ds Max model with a
placeholder material. So we just look at
reference photos from the site and then
texture the model according to that to
create this UV mess that you can see.
So then after kind of the import in
Unreal, we deleted this placeholder
texture and we just did a replace
references with a proper Unreal material
that we built and prepared for. I mean
it wasn't a sophisticated solution at
all and it became quite complex but as
you do we just went on with it anyway.
And we did all of this in version 5.2.
That was just the stable version at the
time. I mean one and a half years of
development has passed since that and
that's like 10 years of development in
Unreal time.
And then about this point we just asked
ourselves the big question like why why
are we actually doing this and what are
we supposed to aim for? So we were often
used to just having a very clear goal
and that our actions are just directed
by this goal. But now we just had this
exploratory delivery and we didn't
really know what we should spend time on
or what the overall meaning of the
project is. So we consulted the clients
again and asked like is there something
in particular you want us to focus on?
They were like no not really just spend
time on it see what you can figure out.
So we actually just had to step in as
creative consultants to think through
the process and just in order to
actually create a Y. So both we and the
customer, we were on relatively new
ground and we didn't really know what we
would be able to accomplish with with
this new kind of interactive tool within
Arcus. So our job just became much more
to show everything you can do with
Unreal Engine. And that became actually
our focus onward.
And so we did this with something that
we just called scenarios. So looking at
what actually the function of arena is,
it's that an arena always has events or
projects going on. and it's quite just
meaningless to show it completely empty.
So, we just made extremely simple tests
with Unreal's level streaming and we
just were able to show how you could
visualize the arena with more activity.
And so, with this, I mean, we got a lot
more direct use of real-time graphics
that we were able to just toggle these
events on and off within the editor. And
through this kind of little change, we
just started to think more about the
functional aspect rather than the visual
aspect as we've always had. And I mean
this also gave just a proof of concept
to see a function that I mean you could
actually provide a return on investment
that had been made because with these
types of models the interactive spaces
it's not just a game that you can just
sell and kind of get revenue from that
but it's actually a tool to just
reinforce everything about the event
industry itself. So we just saw the
opportunity to actually get some value
here by just working with events in an
entirely new way.
So our client was really happy with this
and felt like this is the first big step
to take when it came to these digital
arenas. So now we got a lot of input and

concrete scenarios that happen or they
want to happen and that is a stayout
west an idea sparked from kind of the
very known Gothberg festival called way
out west. And then since this arena
Scandinavian is it's very used much for
hockey, they just wanted to show up kind
of what's it going to look when the home
team plays in the arena and how can we
develop this further and then of course
at the same time we develop these scenar
what what is it that gives the most
visual effects. So we developed the
restaurants and the shops and sort of
think about kind of the exterior of the
arena and new construction that was
happening as we did this.
But then we need another new Swedish
expression to cook
which means just now the boiled pork is

putting in everything that we want
without having to pay the price. So as
the expression indicates it means that
we've indeed just put ourselves in a
very difficult situation and we just
have many problems ahead.
So I mean the idea wasn't to deliver
this 1 FPS PowerPoint presentation but
an actual interactive experience.
So we needed to kind of look at more
optimizations because since this project
was just Arcis based in the beginning
from our archvis team we never really
needed to think about optimizing
anything on a much larger level. I mean
of course you've always had it in the
back of your mind on projects but it
doesn't really have the same weights as
you kind of need to have in the game
engine. So in a traditional rendering
program, you could just start a
rendering. You could wait an hour,
you'll get an image. But now we should
preferably just have 60 images or more
per second for a pleasant experience. So
we need to think a lot about
optimization. And I mean the first step
was of course just to read up a lot
about GPU light mass and then bake the
light as a traditional game technique.
And suddenly the focus was shifted from
kind of detailing the arena to more
optimizing and checking stuff like light
map density, draw calls and map mapping
and all of that.
And then thanks to I mean the handy tool
GPU profiler, it showed very clearly
that we were just suffocating the arena.
And much of this probably sounds quite
obvious to everyone sitting here, but as
someone used to more old path trace
techniques, you'd have completely
changed your mindset when it comes to
working with a game engine because we
have to just play in their playing
field. And this also meant that I mean
we had to go back to a lot of geometry
and split it up into more manageable

had to consider how we would do the

And then after messing about with kind
of the performance, the latter part of
